Thus have I heard: Once, the Buddha was in the country of Shravasti. The prince was named Jeta, and he had a garden
that was eighty li in area, not far from the city.
The land was flat and even, with many fruit trees, and there were flowing springs and bathing pools everywhere.
The pools were pure and clean, without any insects, bees, mosquitoes, gadflies, flies, or fleas.
The householder Sudatta personally served the Buddha and upheld the five precepts:
not killing, not stealing, not engaging in sexual misconduct, not deceiving, and not drinking alcohol.

He saw the truth and attained the stage of stream-entry. He always enjoyed giving generously and providing relief to the poor. People called him AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada, the giver of alms to the orphaned and destitute.
Sudatta wanted to build a monastery for the Buddha. He searched everywhere, and only the Jeta Grove was suitable. He then asked to purchase it.
Prince Jeta said:
If you can cover the ground with gold coins, leaving no gaps, then I will give it to you.
Sudatta said:
Yes!
I will listen and buy according to the number.
Jiji said:
I was just joking.
The dispute was in full swing, and the elders of the state advised:
Since the price has already been decided, it is not appropriate to regret it again.
So they listened and gave it to him.
Sudatta silently thought:
Which treasury of gold is sufficient?
Jiji thought he was regretting:
Disliking the high price, he has stopped.
He said:
It's not because of the high price.
I was just thinking about which treasury of gold to take out.
He immediately had people carry out gold on elephants, and it was laid out on the ground. In a short while, forty acres were filled.
Jiji thought with admiration:
The Buddha must have the great way, causing this person to value the treasure so lightly.
Stop here, do not take out any more gold. The garden land belongs to you. I myself wish to offer the trees to the Buddha.
They then agreed with each other and established the monastery.
They each offered it to the Buddha.
The Buddha stayed there with 1,250 Å›ramaá¹‡as, and therefore it was called Jetavana AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada-ÄrÄma.
The king was named Prasenajit. The entire palace and the people all served the Buddha and offered the Å›ramaá¹‡as clothing, food, bedding, and medicine as appropriate.
When there is no Buddha in the world, various paths flourish, like torches illuminating the darkness;
When there is a Buddha in the world, all heterodox paths cease, like the fire losing its light when the sun rises.
Originally, the people of the country served five hundred non-Buddhist practitioners. At that time, the heterodox paths were all abandoned.
The non-Buddhist practitioners then became jealous and schemed to slander the Buddha, hoping to be respected and served instead.
One of their female disciples named AÅ›okadattÄ said:
Teachers, do not worry.
I can make people stop respecting the Buddha and serve the teachers as before.
From now on, I will adorn myself daily and come and go between the Buddha and the Å›ramaá¹‡as.
After a month, you can kill me in silence and bury me between the Jetavana trees, pretending to search for me.
The people will say:
'We often see this woman coming and going from the monastery.'
They will then go to the king and report it, asking for officials to search for me. They will cry and bring out the corpse.
They will speak of my licentiousness and lack of moral conduct.
When the people of the country hear this, they will surely abandon the Buddha and serve the various teachers.'
The teachers said:
Good.
The woman did as she was told, coming and going for a month.
The teachers had four people kill her together and bury her.
They then searched for her and went to the palace to report:
A woman has gone missing. Everyone saw her going to the places of the Å›ramaá¹‡as every day. We ask for officials to search for her.
The king then ordered the officials of the outer ministry to go with them.
The teachers then pretended to wander around three times, brought out the corpse, loaded it in a carriage, and went around crying everywhere, saying:
The way of Å›ramaá¹‡as is that precepts should be pure, yet you have sex with another's wife.
Fearing that the matter will be exposed, you kill and hide her. What kind of way is this?
The people of the country, upon hearing this, had many who believed it, but only those who had attained the Way knew it was flattery.
The Buddha then ordered the Å›ramaá¹‡as:
Do not enter the city for now.
After seven days, the truth will be revealed.
On the morning of the eighth day, the Buddha sent Ä€nanda to the streets to say:

Those who speak falsely and slander others will have their mouths reek according to Heaven. Those who falsely accuse the innocent will enter hell after death and suffer for a long time in their foolishness and resentment.
The people of the country, upon hearing these words, all said to each other:
The Å›ramaá¹‡as must be pure, so the Buddha said these words.
The king had people secretly watch and saw that the non-Buddhist practitioners secretly congratulated each other and gave gifts to the four people.
According to the non-Buddhist practitioners' rules, those who knew more scriptures would get more shares.
One person was dull-witted and received a small share, and became angry, saying:
I should get more than you.
You all killed people together, yet you falsely slander the Buddha and get less than me.ğŸ”½ He waited for an opportunity, took it, and brought it to the king.
When he arrived, he told the truth, and the conspirators were arrested.
The king and his ministers all went to the Buddha;
AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada and other faithful laymen, as well as countless people of the country, all went to the Buddha.
When they arrived, they made prostrations and sat to one side.
The king clasped his hands and said to the Buddha:
I have heard this slander, and none are not confused.
Only the Buddha is truly pure and immeasurable.
I do not know the reason, why is this so?
The Buddha told the king:
The rise of slander is all due to greed and jealousy, and this has been so for a long time, not just now.
The king said:
I wish to hear it.
The Buddha said:
In my past lives, countless eons ago, when I was practicing the bodhisattva path, I always cultivated the mind of compassion, wishing to liberate all beings.
At that time, there was a country called Poluonayi, vast and magnificent, with a flourishing population.
Within it, there was a brahmin surnamed Gautama, who was exceptionally talented and far-sighted, the foremost in the country.
He had three sons, and the youngest was incomparably handsome.
His father marveled at him and held a great assembly, inviting various spiritual practitioners and relatives from near and far, holding the child to show them.
The masters said to each other:
'This child is good at the Way and has the marks of a sage. He will surely become a national teacher.'
He was thus named Bo.
Bo loved learning from a young age, and his talents surpassed those of others. He thoroughly understood all the scriptures and the ninety-six kinds of worldly arts.
He knew everything about the destinations of life and death, the collapse of mountains and earthquakes, calamities and misfortunes, medical prescriptions, and exorcisms;
he could resist lustful thoughts and subdue sorcery;
He was fully equipped with military strategy, yet his nature was compassionate and benevolent.
After Gautama passed away, his two older brothers were jealous of him and often sought to divide him, saying:
Boluo loved learning since childhood, and his expenses in serving teachers should be less than his share.
His mother pitied him and often advised his two sons, but the two sons did not stop.
Boluo saw that his older brothers' intentions were strong and thought to himself:
Human life is all for the suffering of greed.
If I do not leave, my older brothers will never stop.
He then reported to his mother himself, seeking to go and study the Way, and his mother immediately allowed it.
Boluo then left and approached a wise teacher, becoming a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
In the mountains, he attained the four foundations of mindfulness by himself:
First, being kind to sentient beings, like a mother loving her child;
Second, having compassion for the world, wishing to liberate it;
Third, understanding the meaning of the Way, the mind always joyful;
Fourth, being able to protect, not committing any offenses.
He also attained the four intentions praised by the Buddhas:
First, to restrain greed and lust;
Second, to eliminate anger;
Third, to remove deluded thoughts;
Fourth, to not be happy when obtaining pleasure, and not be sorrowful when encountering suffering.
Moreover, to cut off the five desires:
The eyes do not greedily pursue forms;
The ears do not greedily pursue sounds;ğŸ”½The nose does not greedily pursue fragrances;
The tongue does not greedily pursue flavors;
The body does not greedily pursue smoothness.
Using the way of wisdom and skillful means, he transforms the world, causing people to practice the ten wholesome deeds, be filial to parents, and respect teachers and elders;

For those with doubts, he makes them believe in morality and virtue, knowing that there is life after death, that doing good brings blessings, and that doing evil brings misfortune, and that practicing the Way leads to attaining the Way;
For those who are in distress, he helps them to be released from it;
For those who are sick, he provides them with medicine.
Those who follow Bo's teachings, upon death, are all reborn in the heavens.
Wherever there are calamities such as floods or droughts, wherever Bo goes, they are immediately pacified, and all harm is eliminated.
At that time, there was a great country, peaceful and prosperous, with many people.
The king's name was Ramatha. The four ministers he appointed were exclusively engaged in crookedness and evil, indulging in lust, theft, and deceit, oppressing and robbing without satiation.
The people suffered from their poison, but the king was unaware.
Bo felt pity for them and went to the outskirts of the city, staying with the ascetic Satha for seven days, then entered the city to beg for food.
The king, from his observation tower, saw that Bo was young, with an upright appearance, and walked with distinction, and felt great love and respect for him. He immediately came out to greet him.
The king said:
I wish the Daoist would stay.
I have a monastery not far from the city. You can stay there. I will provide your needs.
Bo said:
Yes!
The king was delighted and said:
I wish to invite you. Tomorrow and every day after, you can eat in the palace.
Bo said:
Good!
The king returned and told the queen:
Bo is no ordinary person. You will see him tomorrow.
The queen was delighted.
Under the bed was a dog named Bingji, who also heard this and was delighted.
The next morning, Bo entered the palace. The king and the queen welcomed him and bowed to him. They offered him a golden bed, a woolen blanket, and a silk quilt.
Bo wanted to sit down, and the dog came forward and licked his feet.
The king himself got up and served water, respectfully offering him food.
Afterward, they both went out to an outer monastery.
Bo explained to the king the methods of governing the country. The king was greatly delighted and invited Bo to stay, asking him to govern the country together with the four ministers.
The four ministers were foolish and timid, not skilled in warfare. They knew they were greedy and corrupt, always fearing the king would find out.
One minister said:
When a person dies, their spirit is extinguished and does not come back to life.
Another minister said:
Poverty and wealth, suffering and joy, are all created by Heaven.
Another minister said:
Doing good brings no blessings, and doing evil brings no misfortune.
One minister relied on his knowledge of astrology.
However, they were all sycophants, not loyal officials.

Bo was intelligent, highly talented, brave, benevolent, righteous, respectful, faithful, and spoke little. His words were always accompanied by a smile, never hurting others' feelings. He was pure, desireless, restrained, and had few affairs.
His governance was not complicated, he could foresee disasters, he could control ghosts and spirits, and he could revive the dead.

He loved the people like his children and taught them the Way - not to be deceitful, to not go hunting, fishing, shooting birds and beasts, to not kill, steal, engage in sexual misconduct, deceive, slander, flatter, or be jealous or angry - he transformed them all to be good.
After his governance, the country was peaceful, the weather was timely, the five grains were abundant;
The officials followed the law and no longer troubled the people;
Bo's governance was non-action, he alone valued serving the Buddha;
The Å›ramaá¹‡as recited and practiced the four paths morning and evening.
His sister's son was also virtuous and wise, always looking up to Bo as his teacher.
Those in the country who loved learning mostly relied on and followed him.
The king had no more worries and entrusted everything to Bo.
The four ministers were afraid and could not act recklessly. They gave rise to feelings of jealousy and schemed to deal with Bo;
They pooled their wealth, each contributing one million, and when the king went out, they presented it to the queen, saying:
'We sincerely offer everything in the household, as well as ourselves, our wives, and children, to be your slaves.
We wish to report a matter and hope you will listen.'
The queen, greedy for the fine treasures, accepted them and replied to the four ministers, saying:
'Speak it.'
The four ministers said:
'The one the king reveres, Bo, is dressed in coarse clothes, like a beggar.
Seen staying too long, he does not think of the kindness of the country, daily leading the queen to evil, teaching the king to stay far from the bedroom.
I secretly think that the time for the queen to have a child is approaching, but if we miss the time, the royal lineage will be cut off.
Please think about it carefully!
If we do not remove Bhrgu, I fear there will be regrets later.'
The queen became angry and said:
'The king believes this person and does not know his evil.
Let us each return home for now.
I will worry about it myself, so that tomorrow the king will not see Bhrgu.'
The queen sent the four ministers out and then yellowed her face with turmeric, disheveled her hair, and lay down.
Soon the king returned, and the palace ladies told the king:
'The queen is unhappy.'
The king, who normally held her in high regard, entered and asked her again and again, but the queen did not respond.
The king then became angry and said:
'Who has committed a crime that deserves to be executed?
Whom do you want me to punish for this?'
The queen then began to weep and said:
'It's just that the king does not listen to my words.'
The king said:
'You may speak, I will not go against you.'
The queen then said:
'When the king just left, Bo came and told me:
Now the king is old and decrepit, unable to listen to state affairs.
The officials and people of the country all submit to me. You can plot with me and share this joy.
Now he has been schemed against by this beggar, which is why I am worried.'
When the king heard these words, he was like a person choking, unable to swallow or spit out, afraid of regretting not using him, and afraid of disorder if he did use him. He thought:
'Bo has been assisting me for twelve years, always with loyal governance, worrying about the country and removing troubles. Far and near rely on him.
He is a treasure of this country, and cannot be punished.'
The king said:
'If Bo is punished now, there will certainly be great chaos later.
For the sake of the myriad people, let us endure this for now.'
The queen then threw herself off the bed, raised her voice and cried out:
'If you do not punish BÅ, I will stab myself and throw myself from the tower. I cannot bear to see it.'
The king again said to her:
'You also know the Dharma.
This is not a small matter. Let us discuss it together.'
The queen returned to her seat.
The king said:
'The way of the monks cannot be harmed with swords and sticks. We should gradually send them away and reduce their provisions.
Those who come tomorrow should not pay homage, but only bow with cupped hands;
Give them wooden beds to sit on in the hall;
Cook bad rice and serve it in earthenware vessels.
In this way, they will be ashamed and will leave on their own.'
When the king said this, Binge was displeased.
The next morning, the queen immediately followed the king's instructions and ordered the kitchen staff.
When BÅ entered the palace, Binge barked and snarled under the bed.
When BÅ saw the dog barking, the queen bowing with cupped hands, and the arrangements made, he immediately knew there was a plot against him and thought to himself:
'I wish to do no harm to others, but people turn around and harm me.
In this case, I should avoid them and enter the deep mountains.
Small grudges become great, they cannot be taken lightly.
Since they have used schemes against me, I should be cautious.
Generally, a person's body may be weak, but practicing what is right makes one strong.
Now I have my own food bowl, water bottle, leather sandals, umbrella, and water strainer, this is sufficient.'
After Bo ate, he packed up his belongings and was about to leave.
The king was startled and stood up, saying:
'What is this hurry?
' He turned to his wife and said:
'You have caused me to lose the intention of a sage.'
He then went forward to pull Bo and asked:
'Where are you going?'
Bo replied:
'I have been governing the country for the king for twelve years, but I have never seen the king bark like this before.
This must be a plot, so I wish to leave.'
The king said:
'It is true.
Now seeing Bo's intentions, I realize the subtle is very clear.
I wish you to admonish and restrain yourself, and punish the evil people!
There is no need to leave.'
Bo said:
'The king's previous intentions were generous, but now they have become thin. Since I have no faults, it is appropriate to leave in a timely manner.
Prosperity has decline, union has separation, good and evil are impermanent, misfortune and blessings pursue one.
Friendship that is not firm cannot be closely associated with. If one is not restrained in intimacy, after a long time it will certainly leak and overflow.
Like drawing water from a spring, if dug too deep it becomes turbid. Associating with the wise makes one wise, learning from the foolish increases delusion.
Seeing often gives rise to arrogance, being distant leads to resentment.
A good friend who is welcoming receives one in a timely manner. If one is respectful towards a close friend, the friendship will become stronger over time.
An unwholesome friend pretends to seek but does not match, skillfully speaking with advantageous words, merely associating without sincerity.
If they treat me with courtesy, I should repay with respect;
if they treat me with contempt, I should immediately avoid them.
There are those who are initially affectionate but later become hostile. When affectionate, one may get close, but when hostile, one should not approach.
Respecting the good and virtuous, and avoiding the wicked, if there is no distinction between good and evil, it is not a path of peace.
One should not falsely encroach upon those who have no faults.
After the wicked have done harm, one should not accept their previous favors.
When people wish to distance themselves, one should not force intimacy.
After affection and love have departed, one should not think of them with longing.
When a bird roosts and a branch breaks, it knows to seek another place to perch. Going and staying should be appropriate, why insist on staying in one place?
A rotten branch cannot be climbed, a disturbed mind cannot be violated.
If people wish to be hostile to each other, when they meet they will not be happy, and if they sing they will not harmonize, one can know they are shallow.
If people wish to be good to each other, they will rush to each other's aid in times of difficulty, and speak with sincere advice, one can know they are sincere.

If one does not associate with the good and does not avoid the wicked, if one first respects but later becomes arrogant, not distinguishing the wise from the foolish, if one does not leave, what need is there?
When a person first bows, now they just raise their sleeves.
If I do not leave, I will be scolded and driven out.ğŸ”½First offering a golden seat, now setting up a wooden bed;
First filled with precious vessels, now using earthenware bowls;
First rice, now inferior rice.
If I do not leave, I will just eat off the ground.
When acquaintances meet, the host looks at them, one night is like gold, two nights are like silver, three nights are like copper.
The evidence is like this, if I do not leave, what am I waiting for?
The king said:
The country is prosperous and the people are at peace, all due to Bo's power.
If you abandon it now, it will be ruined later.
Bo said:
There are four things in the world that destroy themselves:
Trees with abundant flowers and fruits break their own branches;
Poisonous snakes contain venom that turns against their own bodies;
If the assistants are not virtuous, it harms the state;
If people do evil, they die and enter hell.
These are the four things that destroy themselves.
The sutra says:
Like iron produces rust
And corrodes its own form.
The king said:
The country lacks good advisors, and I truly rely on Bo.
If you want to entrust me, this will surely lead to danger.
Bo said:
Ordinary people have four ways to endanger themselves:
Trusting in other families, serving as a witness for others, acting as a matchmaker for people's wives, and listening to and using evil words.
These are the four ways to endanger oneself.
The sutra says:ğŸ”½The foolish person's actions
Bring harm to themselves. Indulging in pleasure and letting the mind run wild,
Later they bring about grave misfortune.
The king said:
My teacher and friend Bo is always lighthearted. I should forgive his shortcomings and not abandon him.
Bo said:
There are four kinds of friends, which should not be unknown:
There are friends like flowers, friends like scales, friends like mountains, and friends like the earth.
What is meant by a friend like a flower?
When it is in season, one puts it on the head, but when it withers, one discards it;
when one sees wealth and nobility, one clings to it, but when one is poor and humble, one abandons it - this is a friend like a flower.
What is meant by a friend like a scale?
When the object is heavy, the head goes down, and when the object is light, it goes up;
when there is something to be had, one is respectful, but when there is nothing to be had, one is arrogant - this is a friend like a scale.
What is meant by a friend like a mountain?
It is like a golden mountain, where birds and beasts gather and their feathers and fur are illuminated;
when one is noble, one can bring glory to others, and when one is wealthy, one rejoices together - this is a friend like a mountain.
What is meant by a friend like the earth?
The hundred grains and treasures all depend on it, and one provides sustenance and protection, with abundant kindness and not thin - this is a friend like the earth.
' The king said:
'Now I myself know that my aspirations are shallow and thin, and I listened to the words of the evil one, causing Bo to leave.'
Bo said:
'The wise have four things they do not use:
Evil and deceitful friends, flattering ministers, licentious wives, and unfilial sons.'
These are the four kinds of uselessness.
The sutra says:
Evil friends destroy people, flatterers confuse the court, a bad wife ruins the family,
and a bad child endangers the relatives.
The king said:
We have loved each other deeply, and we should remember our old friendship. We cannot abandon each other.
Boeup said:
There are ten things to know about deep love:

Not forgetting when separated, delighting in seeing each other, calling each other to delicious food, enduring excessive words, rejoicing in hearing goodness, loyally admonishing in seeing evil, being able to do what is difficult, not gossiping behind each other's back, resolving urgent matters, and not abandoning in poverty and lowliness.
These are the ten kinds of deep love.
The sutra says:
Transforming evil and following goodness, polishing through the Dharma, loyally and righteously admonishing and encouraging,
righteousness unites with the way of friendship.
The king said:
The evil of the four ministers has caused Boeup to be angry and no longer happy with me.
Boeup said:
'There are eight things to know about disliking each other:

When meeting, changing facial expressions, glancing sideways, speaking inappropriately, saying what is not true, rejoicing in hearing about decline, not being happy hearing about prosperity, slandering others' virtues, and praising others' faults.
These are the eight things.
The sutra says:
Even if one kills in a fair fight, there is still something to be forgiven;
But harboring poison and plotting in the dark is difficult to be close to.
The king said:
It is my own fault, not distinguishing between light and darkness, misled by evil people, and thus losing the sage's intention.
Boeup said:
There are ten things to know about a person being wise:

Distinguishing between the wise and the foolish, recognizing the noble and the humble, knowing poverty and wealth, adapting to difficulties and ease, understanding abolition and establishment, judging one's suitability, entering a country and knowing the customs, knowing where to return when exhausted, being well-versed and knowledgeable, and understanding past lives.
These are the ten things.
The sutra says:
In times of ease, distinguish between friends; in battle, see who is brave; in debate, know who is wise;ğŸ”½in times of famine, recognize the benevolent.ğŸ”½
The king said:
Since I obtained BhrÅ«mra, the inside and outside are at ease.
Today, parting from each other, I will never rely on anything.
BhrÅ«mra said:
There are eight things that can be relied on for peace:

Obtaining one's father's wealth, having good karma, mastering what one has learned, having virtuous friends, having a chaste wife, having filial and compassionate children, having obedient servants, and being able to stay away from evil.
These are the eight things.
The sutra says:
Being born with wealth, obtaining virtuous friends is delightful, not committing any evil,
having blessings and virtues is delightful.
The king said:
The words of the sage are truly delightful in every way.
BhrÅ«mra said:
There are eight delightful things:

Associating with the wise, one can consult the sages. By nature, one is kind and harmonious, and one's deeds improve day by day. Anger can be restrained, and worries can be prevented. The Way and the Dharma are mutually intimate, and friends do not deceive each other.
These are the eight things.
The sutra says:
It is joyful when a Buddha appears, it is joyful when the sutra is expounded, it is joyful when the assembly is harmonious,
harmony always brings peace.
The king said:
Bo is always easy to admonish, why is he so difficult to retain now?
Bo said:
There are ten who should not be admonished:
stinginess, greed, lust, confusion, haste, recklessness, exhaustion, arrogance, delight in fighting, and stupidity.
These are the ten.
The sutra says:
Dharma words are difficult for the stupid to understand, like speaking to the deaf, difficult to transform people,
cannot be admonished and enlightened.
The king said:
Like me, arrogant and unable to stay away from lust.
'Boe, having attained the unconditioned, no longer speaks to me?'
Boe said:
'There are ten reasons why people do not speak to each other:
Arrogance, dullness, fear, joy, shame, stuttering, enmity, hunger and cold, business, and meditation.
These are the ten reasons.
The sutra says:
If one can practice what one preaches, that is good. If one cannot, one should not speak empty words.
Falsehood lacks sincerity and is disregarded by the wise.
The king said:
'A bad wife has a beautiful appearance and is skilled in words.
If she has an affair outside, how can one know suddenly?'
Boe said:
'There are ten things that can be suddenly known:

Disheveled hair, tilting head, changing complexion, sweating, loud voice, laughing, improper gaze, accepting their jewelry, looking over walls, frequently visiting neighbors, liking to go out into the wild, and delighting in associating with prostitutes.
These are the ten matters.
The sutra says:
Women are difficult to believe in, their sweet words deceive people, therefore, lofty people
keep their distance and do not associate with them.
The king said:
People are close to and trust women, not knowing their evil.
Boeup said:
There are ten things that cannot be trusted:

The favor of a lord, the intimacy of a woman, relying on one's physical strength, relying on wealth, water-soaked places, dilapidated old houses, the dwelling place of dragons, being sued by the county government, a person with a grudge, a poisonous insect.
These are the ten.
The sutra says:
It is said that alcohol does not intoxicate, it is said that intoxication does not cause confusion, the favor of a lord and the love of a wife,
are all difficult to rely on and trust.
The king said:
As Boeup said, loving habits give rise to evil, this is what should be feared.
Boeup said:
'There are five things to be jealous of:
Harsh speech that injures others, flattery and delight in fighting, being irritable and unappealing, jealousy and cursing, and double-tongued flattery.
These are the five.
The sutra says:
Giving trouble to others while wanting blessings will bring misfortune upon one's own body,
And lead to widespread resentment.
The king said:
What should one do to be loved and respected by others?
Boeuf said:
There are five ways to be loved and respected:
Gentleness and patience, being cautious and trustworthy, being quick-witted and few in words, actions consistent with words, and growing in thickness over a long time.
These are the five.
The sutra says:
Those who know to love their bodies should carefully guard what they keep, aspire to lofty goals,
And study the right path without obscurity.
The king said:
Who is despised by others?
Boeuf said:
There are five ways to be seen as arrogant:
With long hair and arrogance, dirty clothes, empty and aimless thoughts, unrestrained lust, and unrestrained jesting.
These are the five.
The sutra says:
Concentrate the mind on the right path, like a well-trained horse, without the habit of arrogance,
respected by gods and humans.
The king said:
I wish that Boqian would pay attention and return to the monastery together!
Boqian said:
There are ten things that do not extend to the hall:

Evil teachers, deviant friends, despising sages, arguing against, lustfulness, fondness for alcohol, hasty and stingy elders, ungrateful sons, unchaste wives, and servants and concubines who adorn themselves.
These are the ten.
The sutra says:
Stay far away from evil people, do not befriend the licentious, associate with the virtuous,
in order to perfect bright virtues.
The king said:
Boqian is happy in my country, and there are no troubles in the four directions.
Those who leave today will surely be lamented in the country.
Bo replied:
There are eight things that can bring peace and joy:

Following one's teacher and elders, leading the people with filial piety, being humble and modest, being kind and harmonious in nature, rescuing the distressed and rushing to help, being considerate and loving others, reducing taxes and expenses, and pardoning past grudges.
These are the eight things.
The sutra says:
Cultivating all virtuous roots, contemplating before acting, only saving people's lives,
bringing peace and joy for one's whole life.
The king said:
I always think of Bo, how could I forget?
Bo said:
The wise have twelve thoughts:

At cockcrow, think of repentance and making merit. Early in the morning, think of bowing and paying respect to elders. When facing matters, think of being prepared. When staying somewhere, think of avoiding danger and harm. When speaking, think of being sincere. When seeing faults, think of admonishing with loyalty. For the poor, think of providing aid and protection. If you have wealth, think of practicing generosity. When eating and drinking, think of moderation. When eating others' food, think of being fair. When leading the masses, think of using kindness and rewards. When military equipment, think of timely maintenance.
These are the twelve.
The sutra says:
Cultivate what needs to be done, and consider being prepared. New projects arise daily,
Never missing the right time.
The king said:
How can we find a great sage to keep Bo Yi here?
Bo Yi said:
There are ten great sages:

Practicing and studying the lofty and distant, not violating the scriptures and precepts, respecting the Buddha and the Three Jewels, receiving goodness without forgetting, restraining desire, anger, and delusion, cultivating the four immeasurable minds, delighting in practicing kindness and virtue, not disturbing sentient beings, being able to transform the unrighteous, and not confusing good and evil.
These are the ten practices.
The sÅ«tra says:
It is difficult to encounter an enlightened person, and they are not common. Wherever they are born,
Their relatives are blessed.
The king said:
My transgression is grave!
Raising evil people, causing BÅ to leave in anger.
BÅ said:
There are fifteen great evils:

Liking to kill, robbing, lusting, deceiving, flattering, vain adornment, fawning and slandering, falsely accusing the virtuous, greed and indulgence, unrestrained indulgence, envying the virtuous, defaming the Way, harming the sages, and not considering misfortune and guilt.
These are the fifteen.
The sÅ«tra says:
'Cruelty, greed, slander of the virtuous, and improper conduct,
After death, one falls into a bad path.'
The king said:
'I am ashamed that I did not understand what Bo Yan said.'
Bo Yan said:
'There are ten things to be ashamed of:

The ruler does not understand governance, the minister and son are not polite, favors are not repaid, mistakes cannot be corrected, two husbands for one wife, pregnancy before marriage, practice not accomplished, a man with a weapon cannot fight, a stingy person sees giving, slaves and servants cannot be used.
These are the ten.
The sutra says:ğŸ”½ 'If there are people in the worldğŸ”½Who can know shame and conscience,
They are easy to guide and advance,
Like urging a good horse.'
The king said:
'I just thought:
Knowing there is a way is difficult to bend.'
Bo Yan said:
'There are twelve difficulties:

Even if it is difficult for the foolish to be diligent, difficult for the timid to control the brave, difficult for enemies to meet together, difficult for the unlearned to debate, difficult for the poor to repay debts, difficult for an army to be without a general, difficult to serve a ruler for one's whole life, difficult for the unfaithful to study the Way, difficult for the wicked to hope for rebirth in the heavens, difficult to be born during the time of a Buddha, difficult to hear the Buddha's teachings, and difficult to practice and accomplish - these are the twelve.
The sÅ«tra says:
Human life is difficult to obtain, encountering the Buddha is difficult, the Dharma is difficult to hear,
and being able to practice what is heard is difficult.
The king said:
Now discussing with BhrÅ«m, I gain wisdom.
BhrÅ«m said:
Briefly speaking of the essentials, there are forty-five things that people should know:ğŸ”½Cultivating one's dwelling;
Harmonizing one's household;
Being close to the nine clans;
Trusting in friends;
Learning from a wise teacher;
Serving must be good;
Talent is lofty and wisdom is far-reaching;
It is appropriate to guard with goodness;
When wealthy and noble, practice kindness;
When managing wealth, be prudent;
If you have wealth, expand your business;
If your child is young, do not entrust them with wealth;
Associate with those who are good;
If you have a good relationship, do not trust them;
If your wealth is in the county office, worry about getting it out early;
When buying and selling, be honest and do not deceive;
Wherever you stay, always inspect first;
Know the value of where you are going;
When entering a country, befriend good people;
Guests should rely on the powerful;
Do not argue with the strong;
Therefore, the wealthy can seek more;
If you are originally poor, do not expect too much;
Do not show treasures to others;
Do not tell your wife about hidden matters;
When serving a lord, respect the wise;
Be generous and take those who are loyal and trustworthy;
The pure can govern the country;
Those who pursue affairs can establish merit;ğŸ”½The annals of teaching and transformation, filial piety is the basis;
The righteousness of teachers and disciples, value harmony and respect;
If you want many disciples, focus on teaching with righteousness;
As a doctor, one should have effective experience. Shallow techniques should not be used.
When sick and weak, one should follow the doctor's instructions;
In eating and drinking, one should take moderation;
When relieving oneself, one should be mindful;
Delicious food should be shared;
In gambling games, one should not risk one's wealth or life;
What is given or borrowed should be personally delivered;
One should support the righteous and not wrongly accuse the innocent;
One should admonish anger with compliance and avoid evil with forbearance;
Whether people are noble or humble, one should be harmonious and friendly;
The way is to uphold the precepts, and purity is paramount;
The greatest way in the world is none other than nirvana.

Nirvana is where there is no birth, old age, sickness, death, hunger, thirst, cold, heat, fear of water, fire, enemies, or thieves. There is also no affection, greed, various evils, or worries. Therefore, it is called nirvana.
Your Majesty should take care of yourself. I now wish to retire.
The king said:
If Bo He wishes to leave, do you have any other admonitions?
Bo replied:
It is like a place that has been washed away by a great flood. Even after a hundred years, a city and walls should not be built there.
The water will definitely return along the old course.
As for a person who has done evil in the past, even if they wish to do good, they should still not be trusted.
If their original evil mind has not been extinguished, they may still do wrong. One should always be on guard against them.
What people wish to do is like digging a pond. If one does not stop digging, one will definitely find a spring.
All matters have gradual progress. A wise person sees the subtle and can save their life.
It is like a person who is good at swimming, cutting through the current and crossing over.
The king said:
I have kept in my heart everything you have said before and after.
The men and women of the entire country are all delighted.
The old evil ones have submitted and dare not speak out.
I wish to hear your words.
If I encounter an extraordinary person, how can I know if they are wise?
Bo said:
'The wise one's questions and answers are of various kinds, and his words are never unwholesome. The teacher's principles are correct. From this we know.
The nature of the wise one is benevolent, gentle, cautious, and virtuous, warm, elegant, and knowledgeable.
He is revered by all goodness, and there is no doubt about it.
Observe his words and deeds, and his mind and mouth are in harmony;
Examine his sitting and rising, and his movements are not false;
Inspect his comings and goings, his attire and actions, and it is enough to know him.
When discussing with the wise, one should understand his intentions. Understanding his intentions is difficult, like holding a blade or poison, and one must be careful.
' The king said:
'If one wishes to serve the wise without losing their favor, what should one do?'
Boe said:
'Respect them and do not despise them. When hearing and receiving, one must practice.
The wise one recognizes truth and embodies the way of non-action.
He knows the past, present, and future, and all return to emptiness.
People are like transformations, the young and strong have old age, the strong and healthy become weak, the living must die, and wealth and nobility are impermanent.
Therefore, one should think of danger when at ease, and of impermanence when in prosperity.
Be kind to the good and banish the unwholesome.
Even if there is enmity, do not do evil in return.
Be gentle and difficult to offend, weak and difficult to conquer.
A wise person is like this, and should not be slighted.
The king said:
'If one serves a wise person with utmost sincerity and respect, will there be blessings?'
Boe said:
'The wise follow the sages and practice benevolence, delighting in opening up the ignorant and bringing out people's wisdom.
In governing the country, one takes kindness and generosity as goodness, and in cultivating the Way, one takes guiding people as right.
In the country's urgent difficulties, one is able to analyze and resolve them, advancing and retreating at the right time without resentment or blame.
Extending grace and giving generously without expecting reward, serving with the attainment of blessings and lifelong peace.
The king should not doubt this. The method of governing cannot lose the Way. Encouraging the people to study goodness is the greatest benefit to the country.
The king said:
'Who can keep Bo Yi?
My heart is sorrowful and agitated, like a madman!'
He wept as he faced Bo Yi, repenting and explaining his mistake.
Bo Yi said:
'Just as one who cannot swim should not enter deep water,
one who wishes to avenge should not harass in advance.
When close friends quarrel, they later apologize to each other. Although knowing reconciliation is good, it is not as good as having no quarrel in the first place.
Not being able to reward goodness, one instead listens to slander.
I am like a flying bird, staying in no fixed place.
The Way values clarity and emptiness, and should not be in the human realm.
Like a wild fire, the trees beside it are scorched;
Rushing water breaks boats, poisonous insects harm people.
One should not disturb those who associate with the wise.
Grasses and trees have different natures, birds and beasts have different kinds;
The white crane is naturally white, and the cormorant is naturally black.
I am different from them, with no desires in the world.
Like an old farmer born and raised in the mountains, giving him fine clothes is of no benefit.
There is a tree in the world called rebounding, planted by its owner, but he cannot eat its fruit;
others secretly take it, and the fruit then appears.
Now the king is like this, those who govern the country well are driven away;
flatterers and deceivers who ruin the government remain to enjoy their salaries.
Guests who stay too long are disliked by the host.
I should withdraw.
The king said:
Human life is of utmost importance, please remember it!
Now I want to rely on myself, and serve Bo Yi better than before.
Bo Yi said:
Although the king says so, it is still not possible to give.
The queen's intentions are bad, I should not stay.

In every household in the world, they cook and eat. The reason why Å›ramaá¹‡as carry their bowls and beg for alms is to enjoy themselves, eliminate greed, uphold the precepts, do nothing, and stay far away from wrongdoing.'
The king said:
'Now that Bo has left, do not cut off all contact. Please come from time to time, so that I will not be resentful.'
Bo said:
'Even if we are close, we still see each other.
I now wish to enter the mountains to cultivate my will.
It is better to remember good things about those far away, than to remember bad things about those near.
The wise understand through analogies. Let me tell you a story:
It is like a person who smears a knife with honey. A dog licks the honey and injures its tongue. Because of greed for a little sweetness, it does not know the pain of the wound.
The four ministers are like this. They only please the mouth, but their hearts are like sharp knives. The king should be very cautious of them.
From now on, if there is any danger, always think of Bo, and all fears will surely be removed.'
Bo continued:
'The owl enjoys the grave, the rats live in filth;
The hundred birds nest in trees, the crane dwells in a polluted pond.
Things have their own natures, and desires are not the same.
I like non-action, like the king enjoys the country.ğŸ”½Although the vessel is coarse and inferior, it cannot be discarded, each has its own storage;
The foolish and lowly are also not to be discarded, each has its own use.
The king should recognize this.
I still know the direction of people's words and thoughts, like birds gathering on a tree, first and last descending between the branches, heading upwards;
Seeing the Bindi dog barking, I know there is a plot inside and outside.
The intention is to be disgusted, so I accept the new.'
Boe said:
'Please withdraw.'
He then rose and left the city.
The king and his wife wept as they saw him off, and none of the people, young or old, did not wail in resentment.
The king went along and asked Boe in detail:
'Who is trustworthy?'
Boe said:
'My sister's son is wise and good. He can be consulted. From time to time, go out together with him to tour the country, observe the people's customs, and learn the news.'
The king said:
'I will follow your instructions.'
He then bowed to Po along with his ministers and people, and they left.
After Po left, the four ministers acted recklessly outside, using flattery and sophistry as their policies;
The queen used witchcraft inside to deceive the king.
The king's mind became confused, and he no longer worried about the country. He indulged in luxury and pleasure, addicted to debauchery day and night.
The officials and clerks levied and collected taxes without reason.
In the fair market, they no longer paid the proper price. The strong oppressed the weak, robbing and snatching from each other, even killing each other, not fearing the law.
The sons of good people were enslaved. The six relations were separated, fleeing to survive.
Disasters occurred one after another, but the king could not know;
The wind and rain were untimely, and the crops were not harvested.
The country was empty and the people were impoverished, with hunger filling the roads, and the sounds of lamentation moved the ghosts and spirits.
The people were sorrowful and frightened, and almost all fled, crying as they went, thinking of Bo.
Bo was like a hawk, overlooking the birds, suppressing the wicked people, and nurturing the people with kindness, like the Heavenly Emperor.
After Bo's elder sister's son, the monk, went to another prefecture, he saw the country in chaos, the villages destroyed, and the people in distress. He returned to tell the king:
The ministers are not governing properly, indulging in robbery and theft, plundering and killing the innocent, and being cruel and merciless.
The people resent it and the gods are angry, and the heavens have repeatedly sent down disasters.
Far and near all know it, but the king is not aware.
If you do not plan early, there will soon be no more people.
The king was then startled and said:
It is indeed as Bo warned.
Those I have entrusted are like wolves among sheep.
Knowing that the people will scatter, like a runaway cart or horse.
Now that the Daoist has informed me, how can I instruct them?
The Daoist said:
The chaos in the country is all due to evil ministers.
The king should devise another plan, the country can still be restored.
I wish to go around and see with my own eyes and hear with my own ears, then I will know the truth.
The king then secretly left with the Daoist to inspect the country.
He saw several dozen young girls, all between fifty and sixty years old, with tattered clothes, crying as they walked.
The Daoist asked:
Why are these girls not married, even though they are of age?
They replied:
We wish for the royal family to be impoverished like us!
The Daoist said:
Your words are wrong.
How can the king, in his exalted position, worry about you?
The girls said:
No, it is not so.
The king's governance is not just, causing the country to be in famine.
At night, they are troubled by thieves, and during the day, they are exhausted by government officials.
If clothing and food are insufficient, who will marry me off?'
The king continued on his way and saw some old women whose clothes did not cover their bodies, who were emaciated and blind, crying as they walked.
The practitioner asked:
'What worries do you all have?'
They replied:
'If we could make the king as poor and blind as us, wouldn't that be wonderful!'
The practitioner said:
'These words are wrong.
You are old and blind yourself, what has the king done wrong?'
The old women said:

'At night we are robbed by thieves, during the day we are taken advantage of by officials, we are poor and gather firewood, and we are bitten by poisonous insects. It is not the king's fault that we are like this?'
The king continued on his way and saw a woman kneeling to milk a cow, who was kicked by the cow and fell to the ground, cursing:
'If I could kick the king's wife like this, I would be happy!'
The practitioner asked:
'The cow trampled you itself, what does the king's household have to do with it?'
She replied:

'The king's governance is not just, causing the country to be desolate and chaotic, not preventing thieves, forcing my good cow to be taken away and trampled by a bad cow. Is this not the king's fault?'
The practitioner said:
'You yourself have no virtue, unable to milk the cow.'
The woman said:
'It is not so.
If the king's household is good, BhrÄtá¹›dharman should stay himself, and the country will not be in chaos.'
The king continued on his way and saw a crow pecking at a frog. The frog scolded, saying:
'I wish for an evil king to be eaten like me, how delightful!'
The practitioner said:
'You yourself are eaten by a crow, does the king protect you?'
She replied:
'I do not expect protection.
The king has no grace, his governance is not just, sacrifices are discontinued, the heavens are dry and the water is exhausted, thus causing my body to be eaten by a crow.'
The frog called out:
'Know that the ruler abandons one evil person to make a family complete, and abandons one evil family to make a village complete.
Those who do not know how to govern lose the people and things, and the world will be full of resentment and lawsuits.'
The Daoist said:
'The people are innocent, yet they cry out and move heaven. The spirit sends a frog to speak like this.
The king himself has seen it, so he should dismiss the evil people, change the past and cultivate the future, and start anew with the people.
If you plant good fields and the rain and dew are timely, what worries are there about not ripening?'
The king said:
'Now, whom should I rely on?'
The Daoist said:
'You should quickly invite Bo Yi.
Bo Yi is benevolent and wise, and if he returns the country will surely be at peace.'
The king returned and immediately sent messengers into the mountains to invite Bo Yi, saying:
'If Bo Yi does not return, I will bow my head and say, I know I have wronged the people and am worried I cannot eat. I must wait for Bo Yi to arrive.
The king is compassionate and benevolent, concerned for the people of the ten directions. Knowing that our country is in decline, he will surely come.
The messenger received the order and went to the king, bowed and said:

The great king sincerely pays respects beyond measure. He knows his own faults are deep and heavy, and that he has gone against the sage's intentions, causing the country to be in decline, with the people impoverished and suffering. He weeps, thinking of the king, unable to eat or drink.
Please have pity and come once to see him.
The king, out of pity for the people, followed the messenger back.
On the way, he saw a dead monkey and deliberately skinned it, wanting to use it to revive the king.
The people of the country heard that the king was coming and all came out of the border to welcome him.
The king arrived outside the city and stayed in an old monastery.
The king came out to meet him, made obeisance, and after exchanging greetings, sat to one side, with palms joined, and apologized to the king, saying:
I was empty-headed and incompetent, oppressing the people with harshness. I beg to repent and reform myself. I hope you will forgive me.ğŸ”½The king said:
Yes.
'Very good.'
The four ministers whispered in each other's ears, and Bo said:
You have no faults. Why not speak openly?
The four ministers angrily said:
Generally, as a Å›ramaá¹‡a, one aspires to heavenly blessings. People all praise goodness. One should not kill a monkey and take its skin.
Bo said:
You are deluded yourselves and do not distinguish true from false.
Heaven knows all that is good and bad;
Suffering and happiness have a basis, and cannot be forced.
If one does evil, the crime will pursue, and even if it is not immediately resolved;
If one does good, blessings will follow, and will never be lost.
Calamities and blessings are in oneself. The foolish consider them far away.
Using my skin to flay and kill a monkey, this is difficult and seems to be so;
You all silently commit evil and do not stop. Do you teach each other to say that life is in heaven, that goodness is useless, and that doing evil brings no misfortune?
The retribution of misfortune and blessings is natural like an echo. The echo responds according to the sound, not falling from the heavens.
You all commit evil, how can you not recognize it yourselves?
Although you want to falsely accuse, it will naturally not be accepted.
This is not admonishing me, but yourselves.
One of you says, When people die their spirits are extinguished and do not revive again. Is this the sage's words?
Does it come from the mind?
You yourself want to do evil, but say doing good has no blessings and doing evil has no misfortune.
The bright images of heaven, the sun, moon, stars, and constellations are arranged above. Who made them?
The four ministers were silent.
Boeuf continued, saying:
'Between heaven and earth, all depend on sin and blessings.

When people do good or evil, it is like a shadow following a form. When the dead abandon their bodies, their actions do not perish. It is like planting grain. The spoiled seeds are discarded below, but the roots, stems, and leaves grow, and the fruit appears above.
The actions continue without interruption, like a lamp or candle that is passed on from one to another. Although the wick is consumed, the flame continues and does not go out.
Actions have their consequences, just as when a person writes at night, the writing remains even after the lamp is extinguished.
The soul follows the actions and continues to be reborn without end.
You all think your intentions are noble.
Is it possible for someone who kills their parents to be without guilt?
The four ministers replied:
One does not pluck the leaves of a tree that provides shade. How much more so for killing one's parents, which should not be without guilt.
Boe said:
Your difficulty with me seems to be correct.
I take this dead skin and still inquire about it. What should be the law for what you have done?
One of you says that when a person dies their spirit is extinguished and does not live again;
one says that happiness and suffering are determined by Heaven;
one says that doing good has no blessings and doing evil has no misfortune;
one relies on knowing how to predict the stars.
Externally yang is good, internally yin is deceitful.
It is like fake gold, with pure copper inside;
Beautiful appearance and eloquent words, but the mind acts like a slanderous thief.
Like a wolf among sheep, the master cannot be aware.

Evil people in the world are also called righteous, with disheveled hair lying on the ground, expounding the sutras and precepts, exclusively practicing flattery and deception, greedily seeking profit.
Foolish people believe and submit to them, like rain covering dust.
The group of demons hate each other, like overflowing water, entering the ocean out of season, causing much damage.
Only the sage can save the world, transforming evil and bestowing goodness, all receiving blessings.
If goodness has no blessings and evil has no misfortune, why did the ancient sages create the sutras and bestow the king with a sharp sword?
The law of action and retribution is natural - the good receive blessings, the evil receive misfortune.
What heaven abhors, misfortune does not last long. Although hidden, later it will not be obstructed.

Therefore, when a country establishes a king, the king governs according to the laws of heaven, employs the wise and capable, rewards the good and punishes the wicked, each according to their actions, like an echo responding to a sound.
When a person's spirit departs, it goes according to their actions, like a wheel turning, never leaving the ground.
Indeed, sin and merit are not to be deceived.
When a person's conduct is sincere, the spirits assist them.
Even if one does not realize it, in the end one will surely suffer misfortune, so one should be cautious, avoid evil, and know shame.
If everyone does good, then the qi they receive should be the same.

Those who do not do good may have some imbalances, such as some having short lives, some having many illnesses, some being ugly, some being poor, some being lowly, some being wise, and some being foolish. Some are blind, deaf, mute, lame, crippled, or have a hundred illnesses, all caused by the evil deeds they committed in their past lives.
Those who receive a hundred blessings - things that people enjoy - it is because they did good deeds in their past lives that this is so.
Accumulating virtue and loyal governance, there are sun, moon, stars, heaven, people, emperors, and nobility, which are clear evidence.
How can it be said to be non-existent?
You should contemplate it carefully and not say it is not so.
' When Bo Yi said this, the king and his ministers all rejoiced.
Bo continued, saying:
'In ancient times, there was a king named Gou Liao.
Sweet fish grew in the pond, which were delicious and had few bones.
The king ordered a person to guard it and have eight fish offered daily.
The guard also secretly ate eight fish every day.
When the king noticed the fish decreasing, he appointed eight more guards to jointly protect it.
The eight guards each secretly ate eight fish every day.
With so many guards, the fish became extinct.
Now, the king is like this. Those he entrusts with are not few, but the chaos increases even more.
It is like a person picking unripe fruit. Not only does it destroy the seeds, but the fruit is also tasteless when eaten.
If the king wishes to govern but does not employ wise people, he will lose his people and later have no blessings.
If the governance of the country is not correct, it will cause the world to have a mind of contention and usurpation.
If a person manages his wealth without diligence, his wealth will diminish day by day.
If a country has brave and martial people who practice warfare, if their intentions are not fulfilled, it will weaken the country.
If a king does not respect morality and virtue, and does not serve the lofty and enlightened, then the wise will not return, and after death the spirit will not be reborn in heaven.
If one plunders and kills the innocent, causing resentment and litigation in the world, then heaven will send down calamities, and one will lose one's reputation.

Governing the country with the law, governing with loyalty, respecting the elders and loving the young, being filial and obedient, and following goodness, will bring peace and blessings in this life and rebirth in heaven after death.
It is like when an ox walks, its path is straight and correct, and the other oxen all follow.
If the noble and the powerful have the Way and lead the people with righteousness, the far and the near will submit to transformation, and there will be great peace.

As a ruler, you should be clear, explore the past and understand the present, know the proper time for action and stillness, be firm and flexible, and obtain the principles. Be kind to the people below and benefit the people, with impartial application.
In this way, you will be wealthy and noble generation after generation, and later you can attain the path to nirvana.
All those present rejoiced and praised him immeasurably.
The king immediately stepped down, bowed, and said:
What Bo just said is like a swift wind blowing away clouds and rain.
Fortunately, you suddenly have compassion and can transform as before.
Bo then got up and followed the king into the palace.
The four ministers were foolish and were thus dismissed.

Bo again governed the country, with kindness and nourishment flowing like rain, wind and rain coming at the right time, the five grains ripening in abundance, the people rejoicing, people from all directions gathering, and the upper and lower levels living in harmony and joy, eventually leading to great peace.
The Buddha said:
I am the one who was Bo at that time.
The practitioner who was the sister's son is Ananda.
King Ramdatta is now Prasenajit.
The queen at that time is now Bhadra.
The dog Pingiya is now Chandaka.
The four great ministers who killed Bhadra are now the four ascetics.
The one who spoke to the frog is now the arhat Udayin who has attained the path.
I have been practicing good deeds and accumulating virtues for countless kalpas as a bodhisattva for the sake of all people, and now I have attained Buddhahood and fulfilled my wishes.
Those who encounter me and hear the sutra should each be diligent and do good without slacking off.
After the Buddha said this, three koá¹­is of people attained the path of practice, all received the five precepts, and joyfully carried out the teachings.
The Sutra of the Buddha's Past Life as Prince Bhadra
